AS AM 1.title: Introduction to Asian American History, 1850-Present
AS AM 1.comments: AS AM W 1 is the online version of AS AM 1.
AS AM 1.description: Historical survey of Asian Americans in the United States from 1850 to the present. Topics include: Immigration patterns, settlement and employment, race and gender relations, community development, and transnational connections.

AS AM 1H.title: Introduction to Asian American History, 1850-Present
AS AM 1H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in AS AM 1; consent of instructor.
AS AM 1H.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 1.Quarters usually offered: Winter, Summer.
AS AM 1H.description: Students receive one unit for the honors discussion section. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

AS AM 2.title: American Migration Since 1965: Asians and others in the United States
AS AM 2.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
AS AM 2.description: An examination of central themes in immigration law and policy, especially after the Immigration Act of 1965.  The class focuses on Asian immigrants, but covers immigration trends comparatively.  Topics include economic integration, interracial conflict, subsequent immigration reforms and their consequences.

AS AM 2H.title: American Migration Since 1965: Asians and others in the   United States
AS AM 2H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in AS AM 2; consent of instructor.
AS AM 2H.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
AS AM 2H.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

AS AM 4.title: Introduction to Asian American Popular Culture
AS AM 4.description: A historical survey of how Asians and Asian Americans have been represented in American popular culture, with an analytical focus on the social and symbolic contents of examples in journalism, literature, theater, and television.

AS AM 4H.title: Introduction to Asian American Popular Culture
AS AM 4H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in AS AM 4; consent of instructor.
AS AM 4H.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 4.Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 4H.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

AS AM 5.title: Introduction to Asian American Literature
AS AM 5.description: Selected major themes in literary texts from Asian American communities, including Japanese, Chinese, Korean, Filipino and Southeast Asian Americans: dislocation/relocation; finding/inventing a usable past; poetics/politics in language; identities/ethnicities.

AS AM 5H.title: Introduction to Asian American Literature Honors Section
AS AM 5H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in AS AM 5; consent of instructor.
AS AM 5H.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 5.Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Honors discussion section may not be repeated.
AS AM 5H.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

AS AM 7.title: Globalization, Gender and Social Inequality in Asian America
AS AM 7.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 7.description: Survey of contemporary social scientific theories and empirical studies of globalization through the experiences of Asian Americans.  Major themes include global capitalism, labor, colonialism, modernity, pop culture, diaspora, race, gender, sexuality and cultural difference.

AS AM 8.title: Introduction to Asian American Gender and Sexuality
AS AM 8.description: Introduction of gendered analysis and intersectionality in the study of Asian Americans from sociological, psychological, and historical perspectives.  Major themes include social construction of femininities and masculinities, family formation, productive and reproductive labor, global capitalism, violence regulating gender and sexuality.

AS AM 8H. Introduction to Asian American.number: 8H. Introduction to Asian American Gender and Sexuality
AS AM 8H. Introduction to Asian American.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in AS AM 8; consent of instructor.
AS AM 8H. Introduction to Asian American.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 8.Quarters usually offered: Winter.
Repeat Comments: Honors discussion section may not be repeated.
AS AM 8H. Introduction to Asian American.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

AS AM 9.title: Race and Resistance: Asian American, Black, Chicana/o and Indigenous Freedom Struggles
AS AM 9.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
AS AM 9.description: Studies US race-based freedom struggles, emphasizing the 1960s-70s, within the context of global decolonization and the study of the "long" movement from the 1930s to the present. Examines how social movements are studied historically.

AS AM 9H.title: Asian American Freedom Struggles and Third World Resistance
AS AM 9H.description: History of Asian American freedom struggles, organizations, leadership models, ideologies, and solidarities, with a particular focus on the 1960s-70s period. The Asian American Movement is studied in the context of US and world history, especially the US Black and Third World decolonization movements.

AS AM 71.title: Introduction to Asian American Religions
AS AM 71.comments: Students must have a cumulative for the proceeding quarter(s). Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 71.description: Survey of the major themes and issues in Asian American religious history, belief, and practice. Topics include the problem of orientalism; Buddhism and race; Asian American forms of Christianity; religion's role in immigrant and second-generation identity; Asian American contextual theologies.

AS AM 79.title: Introduction to Dramatic Writing
AS AM 79.description: A intensive introduction to playwriting for beginning dramatists. Students will read and analyze the structure of plays, write and stage their own short plays, and gain experience acting in and directing each other's work. Homework for the course includes a series of written and performance-based assignments.

AS AM 100AAZZ.title: Specific Asian Ethnic Groups
AS AM 100AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided the letter designations are different.
AS AM 100AAZZ.description: The historical and contemporary experiences of specific Asian ethnic groups.

AS AM 101C.title: Teaching 4 Social Justice
AS AM 101C.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies
AS AM 101C.description: This interdisciplinary course will highlight how a curriculum focusing on racial, ethnic, gender, and LGBTQ studies is central to teaching and learning within diverse societal contexts. This grounding is essential for K-12 teachers in History and English/Literature. Through a social justice framework, students will learn how classrooms are enhanced by Ethnic and Feminist Studies, placing graduates within the forefront of educational initiatives that position teaching and learning within an inclusive and equitable paradigm.

AS AM 107.title: Third World Social Movements
AS AM 107.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 107.description: Racial comparative analysis of Third World social movements. Study of impact of historical context, political economy, racial formation, and gender dynamics on activism of Asian, Black, Chicana/o, Indigenous, Puerto Rican communities in the United States; also attention to global struggles.
AS AM 107.recommended_prep: As least one lower-division course in the Social Sciences or   Humanities.

AS AM 108.title: Asian American Academic Rhetoric
AS AM 108.prereq_description: Junior standing or higher. Instructor approval required.
AS AM 108.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 108.description: Advanced workshop for refining academic writing skills.  Students will assess scholarly essays from various disciplines in Asian American studies. Course will refine mechanics of argumentation and analysis, but especially use of language, to produce academic prose that is rigorous: precise, concise, clear.

AS AM 109.title: Gender and Labor in Transnational Asian America
AS AM 109.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 109.description: Examines Asian American women and the politics of labor. Will equal pay for equal work resolve long-standing inequities? Why are women of color over-  represented in certain kinds of jobs? We will examine women's experiences in the gendering of labor.
AS AM 109.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 110.title: Transnational Asian America
AS AM 110.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 110.description: Focuses on "deterritorialized" processes that have emerged due to intensified globalization. Emphasis on three distinct schools of thought (diasporic studies, cultural globalization, and transmigration) that illuminate how people, goods, and ideas intersect across multiple spaces and times.
AS AM 110.recommended_prep: As least one lower-division course in the Social Sciences or Humanities.

AS AM 111.title: Asian American Communities and Contemporary Issues
AS AM 111.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 111.description: Historical formation of Asian immigrant communities and their social structures and functions; impact of post-1965 Asian immigration on existing communities; issues facing Asian Americans today including education, employment, discrimination, civil rights, political participation, media stereotypes, and anti-Asian violence.
AS AM 111.recommended_prep: As least one lower-division course in the Social Sciences or Humanities.

AS AM 113.title: Asian Americans and the Long Civil Rights Movement
AS AM 113.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 113.description: Examines the Asian American Movement of the 1960s-70s in the "long Civil Rights Movement" framework, connecting with earlier and later activism. Focuses on leadership development, pan-Asian identity, Third World solidarities, feminism, education, housing, and antiwar, among other critical issues.
AS AM 113.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 114.title: Asian Americans and Public Policy
AS AM 114.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 114.description: Presents formal justifications for using racial categories in American public policy. Course presents racial theories about other groups, with particular attention to Asians. Covers period from 1850 to 1990.
AS AM 114.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 115.title: Asian American Communities and Contemporary Legal Issues
AS AM 115.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 115.description: Examines several contemporary developments in American law where Asian Americans have played an important role. These include: changes in immigration rules; affirmative action law; emerging criminal defenses based on cultural background; political districting; and rules about race-based violence.
AS AM 115.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 116.title: Asian Americans and the Law
AS AM 116.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 116.description: Laws impacted the lives of Asian Americans and Asian Americans' contributions to the legal system in the United States. Review of landmark course cases with opportunities for students to analyze legal documents.

AS AM 118.title: Asian Americans in Popular Culture
AS AM 118.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 118.description: A historical survey of how Asians and Asian Americans have been represented in American popular culture and an analysis of alternative models of popular culture. Texts include literature, theatre, television, and film.
AS AM 118.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 119.title: Asian Americans and Race Relations
AS AM 119.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 119.description: Examination of the development of racial ideology and racism, theories of race relations, effects of racism and discrimination against Asian Americans, and contemporary race issues.
AS AM 119.recommended_prep: a prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 120.title: Asian American Documentary
AS AM 120.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 120.description: Analysis of modes of documentary production to negotiate issues of Asian American history, culture, class, and personal identity. Critical readings and discussion of filmic strategies, combined with introduction to documentary pre-  production, culminates in the production of a documentary proposal.

AS AM 121.title: Asian American Autobiographies and Biographies
AS AM 121.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 121.description: Asian American biographies, their socio-political reflections and expressions inscribing the subject in and against culture, relations between intention and form. Readings may include Pardee Lowe, Jade Snow Wong, Monica Sone, Jeanne Houston, Carlos Bulosan, and Maxine Hong Kingston.

AS AM 122.title: Asian American Fiction
AS AM 122.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 122.description: Examination of the ways in which Asian American writers create fiction in order to reflect on pertinent issues concerning Asian Americans, such as race, class, gender, and sexuality. Texts include short stories and novels.

AS AM 124.title: Comparative Ethnic American Literature
AS AM 124.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
AS AM 124.description: Focuses on literature by Asian American writers alongside texts from one or more of the other ethnic American literary traditions.  Generic and thematic coverage will vary.  Emphasis on literary analysis in comparative racial context.
AS AM 124.recommended_prep: A literature course in Asian American studies (such as As Am 5), or   otherethnic studies   departments (such as Black Studies 38A/38B).

AS AM 125.title: Asian American Theater
AS AM 125.comments:
Same course as THTR 180F.
Repeat Comments: This course is a legal repeat of THTR 180F.
AS AM 125.description: Overview of Asian American theater and its political and artistic achievements, from foundational Asian American theater companies and playwrights to contemporary performance artists. Issues addressed include race and ethnicity, gender and sexuality, and intergenerational conflict.

AS AM 126.title: Asian American Poetry
AS AM 126.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 126.description: Historical overview and critical examination of the development of Asian American poetic expression, in relation to Asian American and US literature, and to larger questions of American identity and belonging.

AS AM 127.title: Asian American Film, Television, and Digital Media
AS AM 127.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 127.description: Formal, historical, and cultural issues in the study of Asian American film, television, and digital media practices in independent, Hollywood, and transnational contexts. The role of cinema and visual technology in the understanding of Asian Americans in modern and contemporary culture.
AS AM 127.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 128.title: Writings by Asian American Women
AS AM 128.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 133 Fall 1996 or prior.
AS AM 128.description: Asian American women's writing covering a variety of genres and cultural communities; emphasis on literary analysis of works in relation to central themes of race, family and gender.
AS AM 128.recommended_prep: At least one Asian American Studies course.

AS AM 130.title: Colonialism and Migration
AS AM 130.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 171AA.
AS AM 130.description: Examines the impact of Western imperialism and colonialism on Asian people and nations, and then the subsequent migrations of Asians to the United States.  The course examines the root causes of migration, the response of the United States to Asians immigrants, and changes to immigration law and policy from 1850 to 1965.
AS AM 130.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 131.title: Asian American Women's History
AS AM 131.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 131.description: The lives and changing status of Asian immigrant women, past and present; Japanese and Korean "picture brides"; American-born girls of Asian ancestry; Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Filipino war brides; adopted Asian girls; and diverse lifestyles of Asian American women today.
AS AM 131.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies, History, or Women's Studies.

AS AM 133.title: Science, Technology, and Asian America
AS AM 133.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American 171HH with a grade of C or above.
AS AM 133.description: The origins and development of Asian American representation in science-based fields and the consequences of that phenomenon in US politics, immigration, counterespionage, and images of Asian Americans in popular culture.
AS AM 133.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 134.title: Asian American Men and Contemporary Men's Issues
AS AM 134.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 134.description: An interdisciplinary study of Asian American male identities, masculinities, and bodies; emphasis on literary, sociocultural, cinematic, and popular culture representations; Asian American masculinist discourses as complements to Asian American feminist discourses. Texts include literatures, films, photos, comic books, and essays.

AS AM 135.title: Asian American Queer Issues
AS AM 135.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 135.description: An interdisciplinary survey of the histories, experiences, and identities of Asian Pacific American gays, lesbians, and bisexuals; coming out issues, family and community pressures, and socio-political representation in Asian Pacific American communities and in the mainstream gay movement.
AS AM 135.recommended_prep: a prior course in Asian American studies.

AS AM 136.title: Asian American Families
AS AM 136.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 136.description: The importance of the family in the East and Southeast Asian cultural heritage; family formation in the United States; contemporary Asian American family dynamics; interracial families; changing gender roles and relationships; the family and the life cycle.
AS AM 136.recommended_prep: Prior course in Asian American Studies or Feminist Studies.

AS AM 137.title: Multiethnic Asian Americans
AS AM 137.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 7or 107.
AS AM 137.description: The history, identities, and social relations of multiethnic Asian Americans. Uses fiction, autobiography, sociological and psychological studies of people of mixed racial or ethnic parentage. Considers cognate issues such as interracial marriage.
AS AM 137.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American studies.

AS AM 138.title: Asian American Sexualities
AS AM 138.description: Examines the critical lens of sexuality in studying Asian American culture, history, and politics. Survey of interdisciplinary texts on concepts of sexuality in Asia and America, constructions of sexual difference, denaturalizing heterosexuality and queer theory.
AS AM 138.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 139.title: The "New" Second Generation Asian Americans
AS AM 139.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 171BB.
AS AM 139.description: Analysis of post-1965 Asian American children of immigrants and/or immigrant children. Examination of diverse childhoods such as "brain drain" children, "refugee" children, "parachute" and "transnational" children. Emphasis on gender, class, ethnicity, inter-generational relations, education, sexuality, popular culture, and globalization.
AS AM 139.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 141.title: Asian American Creative Writing
AS AM 141.description: A creative writing workshop focusing on Asian American themes. Different genres are emphasized depending on the instructor's preference and expertise.

AS AM 142.title: Introductory Asian American Performance Workshop
AS AM 142.description: An introductory performance workshop focusing on Asian American themes. Students write original pieces, learn the basic techniques of stage performance, and participate in presenting a public performance at the end of the quarter.

AS AM 144.title: Asian American Visual Culture
AS AM 144.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 144.description: Examining Asian American visual culture through the use of a variety of media: film, television, photography, sculpture, etc.
AS AM 144.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 147.title: Asian American Playwriting
AS AM 147.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 147.description: Examination of various dramatic techniques, dialogue construction, and character development used in writing for the theater. Students create an original short play or performance piece. Some pieces may be developed for a staged presentation.
AS AM 147.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 148.title: Introduction to Video Production
AS AM 148.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 170QQ.
AS AM 148.description: Introduction to video pre-production, production, post-production and distribution of Asian American independent video. Covers fundamentals of production planning, budget, lighting, sound recording and design, editing, and the film festival and distribution requirements for race and independent media projects. Examples of various practices by Asian American independents are explored.

AS AM 149.title: Screenwriting
AS AM 149.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 170RR; legal repeat of Asian American Studies 170RR.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American Studies 170RR; legal repeat of Asian American Studies 170RR.
AS AM 149.description: Writing-intensive course focuses on the craft of screenwriting in the short film, television, and feature film format. Attention to development of visual language, story, structure, plot, conflict, and other alternate modes of storytelling deployed by various Asian American filmmakers. Students complete scripts in various formats.
AS AM 149.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 150.title: Pacific Islander Americans
AS AM 150.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 150.description: Examination of the histories, migration patterns, ethnic identities, family dynamics, community organizations, cultures, religions, health and mental health, social service needs, political concerns, and inter-group relations of people from Hawaii, Samoa, Tonga, Guam, Fiji, and other Pacific Islands.
AS AM 150.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American studies.

AS AM 154.title: Race and Law in Early American History

AS AM 155.title: Racial Segregation from the Civil War to the Civil Rights   Movement
AS AM 155.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
AS AM 155.description: Examines the legal dimensions of white supremacy in American public law after the Civil War.  The course reviews commonly recurring rules and principles about segregation and racial subordination in American society before the 1960's.

AS AM 156.title: Race and Law in Modern America
AS AM 156.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall. Recommended for juniors and seniors.
AS AM 156.description: This course reviews the Civil Rights Movement and American law in the post World War II era, and it concludes with an overview of contemporary debates about race and law. We examine the end of segregation, and review recurring patterns of race-based inequality.
AS AM 156.recommended_prep: At least one lower division course in the social sciences or   humanities.

AS AM 157.title: Asian Americans and Education
AS AM 157.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. Not open for credit to students who have completed Asian American 171II.
AS AM 157.description: A historical and sociological examination of the effects of race and power on Asian American educational experiences. The role of critical pedagogy in the creation of knowledge. The development and impact of ethnic studies and the model minority image.
AS AM 157.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American studies.

AS AM 158.title: Asian American Aesthetics
AS AM 158.comments: Students must have a cumulative 2.0 for the proceeding 3 quarter(s). Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. One prior Asian American Studies course.
AS AM 158.description: Questions, arguments and ideas regarding Asian American aesthetics.  How can we apply traditional western concepts such as beauty, the sublime, and the imagination when considering Asian American cultural production?  Explores the employment of realism, modernism and postmodernism across different genres.
AS AM 158.recommended_prep: One prior Asian American Studies course.

AS AM 159.title: Environmental Justice and Community Health
AS AM 159.comments: AS AM 159 is the same course as ESS 159.
AS AM 159.description: Examines intersection of environmental racism and health justice. With particular focus on California, course explores the political economic infrastructure of urban and rural communities as they confront environmental racism and challenge its impact on community health.

AS AM 160.title: Asian American Politics
AS AM 160.prereq_description: Political Science 12 or Asian American Studies 1 or Asian American Studies 2.
AS AM 160.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 160.description: Survey of the historical and contemporary political experiences of Asian Americans and their pursuits for immigration, equality, citizenship, political identity, racial justice, cross-racial/ethnic coalition building and incorporation into the U. S. political system.

AS AM 161.title: Asian American Religions
AS AM 161.prereq_description: Upper Division Standing or permission of instructor.
AS AM 161.description: Historical and interdisciplinary approach to the themes and issues in the religious traditions of Asian Americans. Topics: the civil religious context, the transplantation of "Asian" traditions into the U.S., Asian American Christianity, Asian American theology.
AS AM 161.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 162.title: Asian American Mental Health
AS AM 162.description: Examination of the current theory and research on the specific psychological issues that affect Asian Americans. Special emphasis on how immigration experiences,cultural values, ethnic identity, and racism influence various aspects of psychosocial functioning.

AS AM 163.title: Asian American Community Studies and Social Justice
AS AM 163.comments: Students must have a cumulative  2 for the proceeding 3 quarter(s). Open tonon-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
AS AM 163.description: Examines models of community organizing, leadership development, and Asian American and Third World social movement history. Study of social issues of inequality and social justice struggles in Asian American, Chicano/Latino, and African American communities.

AS AM 164.title: The Politics of The Global War on Terror
AS AM 164.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 164.description: Examines the politics of terrorism and the "Global War on Terror". Focusing on the impact it has on South Asian, Arab, and Muslim Americans. How have the politics of terrorism impacted the lives of those living in the U.S.
AS AM 164.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 165.title: Ethnographic Research Methods in Asian America
AS AM 165.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 165.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 170AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Asian American Studies - Arts & Humanities
AS AM 170AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different, but only 8 units will apply to the major.
AS AM 170AAZZ.description: Courses focusing on various arts & humanities topics not covered in other Asian American Studies courses.
AS AM 170AAZZ.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American studies.

AS AM 171AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Asian American Studies - Social Science and History
AS AM 171AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, provided letter designations are different, but only 8 units will apply to the major.
AS AM 171AAZZ.description: Focuses on various social science and history topics not offered in other Asian American studies courses.
AS AM 171AAZZ.recommended_prep: a prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 175.title: Theory and Method in Asian American Studies
AS AM 175.comments: Quarters usually offered: Fall. Course is intended for students excelling in the major or minor. Instructor approval is required.
AS AM 175.description: Exploration of the main theoretical orientations that have shaped Asian American studies; race and ethnicity, diasporas, international labor migration, etc. Introduction to several methodologies, including historiography, quantitative social science, literary criticism and ethnography.
AS AM 175.recommended_prep: This seminar is designed for highly motivated students who are interested in research and writing. Students are expected to pursue their own research interests, select a research topic, conduct original research, and craft a 15-page paper using original sources.

AS AM 194A.title: Ethic Studies Teacher Education Seminar
AS AM 194A.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies.
AS AM 194A.description: Designed for students who are Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Asian American and/or Feminist Studies majors in the EXITO (Educational eXcellence and Inclusion Training Opportunities) program. Central to the year-long seminar will be preparations for students' pursuit for a career as K-12 Ethnic Studies educators. Students will have direct assistance for preparing and applying to Masters/Teacher Education Programs as well as professionalization workshops.

AS AM 194B.title: Ethnic Studies Teacher Education Seminar
AS AM 194B.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies.
AS AM 194B.description: Designed for students who are Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Asian American and/or Feminist Studies majors in the EXITO (Educational eXcellence and Inclusion Training Opportunities) program. Central to the year-long seminar will be preparations for students' pursuit for a career as K-12 Ethnic Studies educators. Students will have direct assistance for preparing and applying to Masters/Teacher Education Programs as well as professionalization workshops.

AS AM 194C.title: Ethnic Studies Teacher Education Seminar
AS AM 194C.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies.
AS AM 194C.description: Designed for students who are Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Asian American and/or Feminist Studies majors in the EXITO (Educational eXcellence and Inclusion Training Opportunities) program. Central to the year-long seminar will be preparations for students' pursuit for a career as K-12 Ethnic Studies educators. Students will have direct assistance for preparing and applying to Masters/Teacher Education Programs as well as professionalization workshops.

AS AM 195H.title: Senior Honors Project
AS AM 195H.prereq_description: Open only to Asian American Studies majors, Junior standing or higher.
AS AM 195H.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter. Must have a 3.0 overall grade-point average and a 3.5 grade-point average in courses in the major.
AS AM 195H.description: Offers an opportunity for students who meet the prerequisites to do independent research and to write an honors thesis or produce an honors film/video or performance.

AS AM 196.title: Career Development Seminar in Asian American Studies
AS AM 196.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter. May be repeated. Course meets for one hour every week during the regular quarter.
AS AM 196.description: Course is for majors and other interested students who wish to explore career options under the supervision of a faculty member.

AS AM 197.title: Field Studies
AS AM 197.prereq_description: Open to students who 1) have attained upper-division standing, 2) have at
AS AM 197.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated up to 7 times for a maximum 8 units of credit.
AS AM 197.description: Students will conduct independent field work in Asian American communities. Specific projects include working with community agencies and organizations to evaluate programs, implement new or modified services, and develop community resources.

AS AM 199.title: Independent Studies
AS AM 199.prereq_description: A lower-division Asian American Studies course and 2 upper-division courses; upper-division
AS AM 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter, and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. No more than 4 units per quarter and no more than 12 units total may be applied to the major.
AS AM 199.description: Independent study of topics not covered in the regular curriculum under the guidance of approved faculty member.

AS AM 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Asian American Studies
AS AM 199RA.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 3 quarter(s). Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
AS AM 199RA.description: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research assistance.

AS AM 200.title: Critical Issues in Asian American Studies
AS AM 200.prereq_description: Graduate standing in the social sciences or humanities or instructor consent.
AS AM 200.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 200.description: Graduate Seminar exploring critical themes and major debate in Asian American Studies. Readings cover perspectives that may include history, literature, sociology, anthropology, cultural studies, political science, gender and sexuality studies, psychology, and religious studies.
AS AM 200.recommended_prep: Graduate standing in the social sciences or humanities.

AS AM 209.title: Gender and Labor in Transnational Asian America
AS AM 209.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 109. Quarters usually offered: Summer.
AS AM 209.description: Examines Asian American women and the politics of labor. Will equal pay for equal work resolve long-standing inequities?  Why are women of color over-represented in certain kinds of jobs?  We will examine women's experiences of the gendering of labor.
AS AM 209.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 218.title: Asian Americans in Popular Culture
AS AM 218.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 118. Graduate student standing, course held the same time as AS AM 118.
AS AM 218.description: Critical and historical approaches to popular culture representation of Asian Americans in the United States in films, theater, performance, print media, sports, and music.
AS AM 218.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 227.title: Asian American Television and Digital Media
AS AM 227.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 127. Taught concurrently with Asian American Studies 127.
AS AM 227.description: Asian American film, video, and new media produced within Asian American framework life, culture, and politics or "socio-aesthetics." Moving image production, criticism, and theory is reviewed in order to formulate an analysis of production, authorship, and spectatorship of various forms. Readings of Peter Feng, E. Franklin Wong, Eve Oishi, and others are a must. Students will write two page response papers every week, attend lectures and screenings as part of Asian American 127, meet with the professor weekly, and read extensively in the field of Asia American Film Studies.

AS AM 238.title: Asian American Sexualities
AS AM 238.comments: Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 128. Quarters usually offered: Spring. Graduate students required to write a research paper, or weekly assignments.  This course is taught with undergraduate student AS AM 128.
AS AM 238.description: Examines the critical lens of sexuality in studying Asian American culture, history, and politics. Survey of interdisciplinary texts on concepts of sexuality in Asia and America, constructions of sexual difference, de-naturalizing heterosexuality and queer theory.
AS AM 238.recommended_prep: A prior course in Asian American Studies.

AS AM 240.title: Theory and Production of Social Experience
AS AM 240.comments: Concurrently offered with AS AM 140. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
AS AM 240.description: Graduate level theory and production course. Theory and video production of social experience course focused on performance studies and ethnography in the context of Asian American studies. Central texts in these fields as well as production of performances and ethnographies in video are covered.

AS AM 264.title: The Politics of The Global War on Terror
AS AM 264.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with AS AM 164. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
AS AM 264.description: Examines the politics of terrorism and the "Global War on Terror".  Focusing on the impact it has on South Asian, Arab, and Muslim Americans.  How have the politics of terrorism impacted the lives of those living in the U.S.

AS AM 500.title: Laboratory for Teaching Assistants
AS AM 500.prereq_description: Appointment as a teaching assistant in an Asian American Studies course.
AS AM 500.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.
AS AM 500.description: Supervised teaching of Asian American studies lower-division courses.

AS AM 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
AS AM 596.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
AS AM 596.description: Reading and research in special topics in Asian American studies.
